claim: The 6 most strongly cross-correlated hype terms were key (cross-correlation coefficient, 0.96), diverse (0.95), novel (0.94), critical (0.93), robust (0.92), and promising (0.90) (Figure 1).
title: Figure 1.  Yearly Frequency of the 6 Most Strongly Cross-Correlated Hype Adjectives in PubMed Abstracts and in National Institutes of Health (NIH) Funding Application Abstracts.
caption: Frequency of each word’s use in PubMed abstracts and NIH funding application abstracts is shown. In the panel label in parentheses the correlation coefficient between word frequency in the 2 data sets is given.

claim: The 6 most strongly cross-correlated hype terms that were absent from PubMed abstracts but have since gained popularity were transformative (0.90), nuanced (0.85), scalable (0.84), actionable (0.83), impactful (0.81), and seamless (0.80) (Figure 2).
title: Figure 2.  Yearly Frequency of the 6 Most Strongly Cross-Correlated Hype Adjectives in PubMed Abstracts and in National Institutes of Health (NIH) Absent From PubMed Abstracts in 1985.
caption: Frequency of each word’s use in PubMed abstracts and NIH funding application abstracts is shown. In the panel label in parentheses the correlation coefficient between word frequency in the 2 data sets is given.

claim: In the panel label in parentheses the correlation coefficient between word frequency in the 2 data sets is given.Figure 2.
title: Figure 2.  Yearly Frequency of the 6 Most Strongly Cross-Correlated Hype Adjectives in PubMed Abstracts and in National Institutes of Health (NIH) Absent From PubMed Abstracts in 1985.
caption: Frequency of each word’s use in PubMed abstracts and NIH funding application abstracts is shown. In the panel label in parentheses the correlation coefficient between word frequency in the 2 data sets is given.
